about.bio: an innovative product designer and developer based in london.

intro.title: INTRO
intro.content: The project is defined as ORA Web, a small-scale software system for a contract manufacturing company, focusing on integrating contract production data management and efficiency.

team.title: TEAM & MY ROLE
clientPoints: Founded in 2019, scaled into one of the leading nutrition contract manufacturers in Auckland.
Acquired in 2025 by a China-listed company.
team.context: The factory has no in-house design team, so I operated as the sole designer in cross-functional delivery.
rolePoints: Led end-to-end UX for ORA Web, from problem framing to workflow design and system structure.
Mapped contract-to-shipment processes and translated operational logic into scalable data and UI models.
Facilitated alignment across Finance, Production Planning, Warehouse/Procurement, and Management.
Worked closely with engineering to ensure feasibility and consistent status logic across views.
team.durationDesc: Case study scope: Jul 2023 ‚Äì Aug 2024 ¬∑ Ongoing

scope.title: System Scope
scope.content: This system spans three operational layers across the contract-to-production lifecycle:
points: Decision Makers: They read and consolidated data for timing, risk, and client decisions.
Shift/Planning Managers: They need accurate status and capacity signals to allocate work.
Operators/Executors: They need structured input and clear next-step prompts to keep data reliable.
scope.read: Read: Decide timing and client priorities.
scope.input: Input: Heavy data entry & initial validation.

rationale.title: Project Rationale
rationale.subtitle: Enhancing Efficiency
rationale.quote:
We connect contract-to-shipment data.
So managers stop wasting time on Excel checks.

research.title: Research Findings
research.content1: Instead of jumping straight into generic interviews, I started with quantitative analysis of how the shared Excel file was actually used. By logging user operations, I found that around 54% of actions were pure data input and 37% were just formatting changes‚Äîoften used as reminders or unit conversions.

stakeholders.title: Who are the Users Behind the Data?
stakeholders.description: To understand the "why" behind the manual formatting behaviors, I mapped the stakeholders into three engagement layers. This helped me identify exactly who was struggling with what.
stakeholders.graph_title: Mapping the Humans Behind the Data
stakeholders.graph_subtitle: Categorizing stakeholders by their primary interaction with the system.

groups.name: Shift Managers
groups.context: Connecting dots between orders and capacity.

user_voice.title: From Data to User Voice
user_voice.description: While the quantitative data revealed what was happening (heavy manual entry), I needed to understand the why. I traced these patterns back to the specific users to uncover the root friction behind the numbers.

quotes.text: We spend hours analyzing rows just to get a 'vague feeling' of whether we have the capacity to negotiate more orders.
I‚Äôm juggling design, ordering, and clients every day. I simply don't have time to manually fix spreadsheet formatting.
I need to add notes when things change, but I‚Äôm afraid to break the Excel formulas if I insert a new row.
It would be a game-changer if the data was linked‚Äîso I know instantly when materials or packaging actually arrive.
I constantly switch between different sheets just to verify if the information is actually correct.

design_moves.title: Turning these pain points into three core design moves.

context.pain: Operators often added rows randomly in Excel, breaking formulas and creating "orphan data" that didn't match the contract.
context.strategy: I designed a linear flow: Contract ‚Üí Schedule ‚Üí Report. Users can now only report production on tasks that actually exist.

image.annotation: Tasks are linked to contracts. No more random manual entry.

context.pain: Teams (Finance, Packing, Planning) wasted time switching between different spreadsheets just to find "their" columns.
context.strategy: A Single Source of Truth with role-based tabs. Everyone works on the same live data, but sees a filtered view tailored to their job (e.g., Finance only sees payment status).

image.annotation: One click to filter irrelevant data.

context.pain: Managers relied on "gut feelings" to accept new orders because calculating actual capacity from raw rows took too long.
context.strategy: Transformed the dashboard from a data list into a Decision Tool. It visualizes future capacity and bottlenecks, giving an instant "Yes/No" on whether to take new orders.

image.annotation: Visualizing free slots to help negotiate new orders.

section1.title: From data to decisions: Internal Exception Radar & Process Lead Time
section1.content: To take this project‚Äôs design solution integrate in user‚Äôs daily workflow, I extended the solution into an internal decision-support dashboard. Instead of repeating raw tables, the dashboard focuses on where time is lost and where processes break.
list: The Internal Exception Radar (P1-A) aggregates contract data and flags three key risk types: lead-time breach, payment blocked and material risk.

The Key Contracts Stage Overview (P1-B) then shows which specific contracts are affected and at which internal stage they are stuck. In our analysis, for example, around 68% of delays were linked to material readiness and 45% to production exceeding internal targets, giving management a clear view of the main bottlenecks without digging through spreadsheets.
The Process Lead Time view (P2) visualises how long contracts spend in each stage, and whether we are meeting or exceeding our own SLA targets.
section1.content2: What differentiates this dashboard is that it does not try to show everything. It deliberately moves away from raw, dense data and focuses on:
points: Which contracts are impacted and need attention
section1.content3: This makes it useful for decision-makers who need immediate, actionable signals, not just a static report.

section2.title: Working with the ‚Äúmessy reality‚Äù of stakeholder feedback
section2.content: When I first shared the dashboard prototype, it was intentionally simple: a few focused widgets and a clear story about bottlenecks. That early version quickly triggered a wave of stakeholder responses, such as:
list: Requests for discrepancy alerts between planned vs. actual timelines.
Interest in trend analysis over time, not just a snapshot.
Comments like: ‚ÄúThis data would help me a lot when I talk to our clients.‚Äù
section2.content2: I chose to include this ‚Äúmessy middle‚Äù in my case study because it shows what actually happens after a first design goes live: priorities shift, new expectations surface, and the scope grows.
section2.content3: Instead of treating this as a failure of planning, I used it as a chance to:
points: Clarify which insights are ‚Äúmust-have now‚Äù vs. ‚Äúgood to have later‚Äù.
Refine the dashboard so it could support both internal operations and client-facing conversations.
section2.content4: This part of the story demonstrates my ability to work through ambiguity, respond to evolving needs, and keep the design grounded in what the business really cares about.

reflection.title: Reflection
reflection.subtitle: Using the Kano Model
reflection.content: In my reflection, I used the Kano model to make sense of the different types of dashboard features:
list: Basic expectations: E.g. being able to see contract status and lead time without digging through spreadsheets.
Performance features: Clearer bottleneck visualization that directly improves planning and internal coordination.
Delighters: For example, exception alerts and narrative views that help managers explain issues to clients.
reflection.content2: By mapping stakeholder requests and existing widgets onto the Kano model, I could:
points: Distinguish between "must not fail" basics and "high-impact" improvements.
Avoid overloading the dashboard with nice-to-have charts that don‚Äôt change decisions.
Show that I‚Äôm not only designing UI, but also prioritizing features systematically.
reflection.content3: Including this reflection is my way of demonstrating a growth mindset: I‚Äôm willing to learn, borrow tools from product/strategy (like Kano), and use them to make more grounded design choices.

intro.name: rongze xu
intro.subtitle: product designer & developer
intro.statement: rongze is an innovative product designer and developer based in london.

p.title: Ora Web
p.description: We increased factory management efficiency by integrating contract and production data into a simple ERP tool.

one.title: Innerpeace
one.description: We created a low-cost mental health app for students, optimized to run on affordable Android devices, enabling large-scale testing with a research database and delivering accessible stress-relief at scale.

workloadGraph.title: Workload Analysis
workloadGraph.formattingDesc: Users used colors/borders to mark progress, flag blockers, and create reminders
